entry.title: Combined summary - LN Summit 2023 Notes
entry.summary: In a recent email thread, participants discussed various aspects of Bitcoin network policies and proposed solutions to address issues such as channel jamming and transaction selection. One proposal involved implementing monetary measures to make the cost for attackers scale with their usage, while regular users pay reasonable fees. This could involve charging for bandwidth and compute resources used in message spam and imposing fees for holding funds in liquidity DoS prevention scenarios. Higher fees for actual payments were also suggested to incentivize their prioritization.Concerns were raised about determining small fees and the potential for market influence, but it was argued that market dynamics would help regulate fee levels. The challenge of proving time in case of issues and the reliance on cooperation was also discussed, with suggestions for per-block measurements and considerations for reorg/stale blocks.A specific scenario involving routing paths and payment expiry was analyzed to highlight potential issues with fees and channel closures. It was concluded that this scenario is unlikely and can be addressed by imposing caps on liquidity fees based on route position and expiry time.In another discussion, Antoine proposed a solution for commitment transactions in the Signal group. The suggestion involved using tapscript branches for unilateral closes instead of MuSig2 signing, eliminating the need for storing nonces in persistent storage. Static fees in the Lightning Network were also discussed, with arguments against their suitability in an ecosystem driven by demand and liquidity pricing.The topic of reputation in the network was touched upon, emphasizing the need for reputation accumulation to align with normal node operation to prevent unfair advantages for attackers. The concept of jamming and the valuation of resources were also explored. The idea of paying for the time a HTLC is held in flight was considered, but the lack of a universal clock for proving duration posed challenges.The issue of halting channel progress was raised, with suggestions for a grace period to allow for temporary halts due to software upgrades or connectivity issues instead of strict reputation downgrades.Overall, the email thread and discussion provided valuable insights into Bitcoin network policies and proposed solutions to improve transaction selection, efficiency, and mitigate channel jamming.During the Lightning Network protocol discussions, various proposals and considerations were explored. One proposal suggested using tapscript branch instead of MuSig2 signing for commitment transactions, with MuSig2 signing reserved for mutual closes after negotiating closing fees. This approach reduces the need for nonce storage, as only mutual closes require it. Unconditional fees were discussed as a simple monetary solution for pricing scarce resources, with the suggestion that they should be dynamic rather than static to match liquidity demand.Setting a failure threshold to prevent attacks was deemed challenging, as attackers can aim to fall just below the threshold and attack individual channels through multiple channels. Reputation-based solutions were also considered, but their limitations were acknowledged as they can be gamed by attackers. Jamming, which refers to subjective valuation of local resources by forwarding nodes, was discussed as well.The ideal solution would be to pay for the amount of time an HTLC is held in flight, but proving time when things go wrong is challenging without a universal clock. The conversation also touched on the use of NACK (negative acknowledgment) to indicate progress to the next commitment, although halting channel progress without reputation downgrade was seen as a potential layer violation issue.In addition to these topics, the discussions covered V3 transactions, Taproot upgrade, Gossip protocol versions, multi-sig channel parties, PTLCs, and channel jamming mitigation. The attendees explored different implementation methods and approaches, including the use of scripts, FROSTy, recursive musig, regular musig, and adaptor signatures.Mitigating channel jamming was addressed through monetary, reputation-based, and scarce resource-based solutions. A hybrid approach combining unconditional fees and reputation systems was considered most promising. Other aspects such as versioning, async payments/trampoline, and communication within the Lightning Network community were also discussed.The annual specification meeting took place in New York City in late June, where attendees experimented with transcript-style note-taking. The notes aimed to capture the discussions that occurred during the summit, with a provided link for detailed notes. Gratitude was expressed towards those who attended the meeting and the host, Wolf, as well as Michael Levin for assisting with the note-taking process. These discussions provided valuable insights into ongoing development and improvements in the Lightning Network protocol.
